programme.title: How To Build A Motor Car
programme.desc: With access all areas to the Bentley factory, we see the luxury car manufacturer build a new £170k Continental GT from the bare-metal bolts to the finished car.

programme.title: How To Build A Motor Car
programme.sub-title: How to Build an Aston Martin
programme.desc: Aston Martin open their factory doors in an access-all-areas look at the building of a £237k DBS Superleggera, to see how a 211mph supercar is actually made.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: Focuses on the development of the fortress, featuring examples in Warwick, Edinburgh and Conwy. At Hadrians Wall Fred marvels at the design of Roman toilets, and hes joined by a band of knights in armour to test a castles defences.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: This film celebrates the grandeur of Hampton Court Palace and visits Cragside, one of the first homes to have electric lighting. Fred Dibnah also examines restoration work on a 15th century manor house.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: This edition focuses on places of worship, taking in Preston, County Durham, St Pauls Cathedral and York Minster.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: Fred Dibnah continues his tour of Britains great building feats with a look at our places of work. In Chatham he visits one of our oldest dockyards, while at Armley Mills in Leeds he discovers an early form of fireproofing.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: Fred Dibnah looks at some of the great achievements in civil engineering, from the earliest wrought iron suspension bridge to the Channel Tunnel.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs Magnificent Monuments
programme.desc: Focuses on structures that have been built for arts, leisure and entertainment purposes, including the Globe Theatre, the Victoria and Albert Museum and Blackpool Tower.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Series in which the late Lancastrian steeplejack Fred Dibnah traces the development of industrialisation in Britain. He looks back at some of the sites he visited over the past eight years, such as Queen Street Mill, Ironbridge, the Long Shop Museum and the Black Country Living Museum.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Fred Dibnah described himself as a back street mechanic and believed he was awarded his MBE and honorary doctorates for this reason. His garden was all assembled from scrap and the cast-offs from old mills and factories, but it was probably the finest working example of a steam-powered engineering workshop in the country.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.sub-title: The Machines That Changed the World
programme.desc: Fred shares his passion and enthusiasm for the British machines that changed the world during the Industrial Revolution.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Fred shares his respect for the great engineers of the Victorian age and explores how their belief in the values of hard work and enterprise drove them on.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Fred shares his respect for the Victorian age, the era that he admires the most and the time he would have most liked to have lived and worked in.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: One of Fred Dibnahs passions was restoring engines and chimneys. Amongst his triumphs was his steam traction engine, lovingly restored over 27 years.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: From a very young age, Fred had a passion for steam-powered engines and machinery and he spent a large part of his life studying their construction and history.

programme.title: Fred Dibnahs World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Freds fascination with mining led him not just to dig his own coal mine in his back garden, but was also used to make viewers aware of the skills of miners and engineers, and the dangers and hardships faced by miners throughout history.

programme.title: The Life of Mammals
programme.desc: David Attenborough looks at an amazing variety of monkeys from all over the world, including red howler monkeys in Venezuela, capuchin monkeys in the Costa Rican swamps, and guenon monkeys in West Africa.

programme.title: The Life of Mammals
programme.desc: David Attenborough encounters chimps hunting for meat in a very human way, visits an ancient mud city in Mali, and considers the size and capacity of both ape and human brains - with an incredible journey into the human brain to demonstrate its power.

programme.title: Gorillas Revisited with Sir David Attenborough
programme.desc: Ever since they were discovered over a century ago, gorillas have been threatened by loss of habitat, poaching, disease and political instability, But despite all odds their numbers have increased. Sir David tells the extraordinary tale of how conservationists like Dian Fossey have battled to save the mountain gorilla from the brink of extinction.

programme.title: Attenboroughs Wonder of Song
programme.desc: Sir David Attenborough chooses his favourite recordings from the natural world that have revolutionised understanding of song. Each one, from the song of the largest lemur to the song of the humpback whale to the song of the lyrebird, was recorded in his lifetime.

programme.title: Attenborough and the Mammoth Graveyard
programme.desc: Sir David Attenborough joins an archaeological dig uncovering Britains biggest mammoth discovery in almost 20 years. In 2017, in a gravel quarry near Swindon, two amateur fossil hunters found an extraordinary cache of Ice Age mammoth remains and a stone hand-axe made by a Neanderthal. Professor Ben Garrod joins the team at DigVentures during the excavation as they try to discover why the mammoths were here and how they died.

programme.title: Robson Green: Worlds Most Amazing Walks
programme.desc: Robson explores the legendary Trail of the Eagles Nest, a stunning 100-mile route connecting a group of medieval castles perched across the limestone highlands.

programme.title: Flipping Bangers
programme.desc: Gus and Will want an Eastern Bloc car to see whether the old Skoda jokes were deserved. Bidding low they win an orange Estelle - but can they add value?

programme.title: Allo Allo!
programme.desc: Hitler sends Herr Flick to retrieve a valuable painting, so Rene tries to mislead them by creating a forged version and smuggles out the original.

programme.title: TOTP 2
programme.desc: Mark Radcliffe takes us on a memorable look back at some classic Wham! performances on `Top of the Pops.

programme.title: TOTP 2
programme.desc: Mark Radcliffe takes us on a memorable look back at some classic Duran Duran `Top of the Pops performances.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: A rare Honda S800 sports car from 1967 takes Dereks fancy, and a couple of very different Ford Capris with long histories go head-to-head at the auction.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: The Mathewsons sell a 1958 Bedford D122 and a 1969 Vanden Plas Princess. They also meet a collector who may be willing to finally part with his huge hot hatch collection.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: There is a triple collection of desirable cars in store for Derek when an MG Midget, an Austin-Healey frogeye Sprite and an RS2000 come up for auction.

programme.title: How To Build A Motor Car
programme.desc: The Morgan Motor Company open their doors to reveal how they carefully construct by hand the £90,000 Plus Six, with 170 craftspeople working 100 hours over 30 days.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: Derek waxes lyrical about a pristine Jaguar XJ8 and a Ford Model T van tests his driving skills.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: Derek travels to the Yorkshire coast to pick up a 1963 Austin J2 Paralanian campervan, described as the Rolls Royce of campervans.

programme.title: World at War
programme.desc: Stricken by the humiliation of defeat and the harsh terms of the Treaty of Versailles, Germany looks to one man for a resurgence of hope and dignity - Adolf Hitler.

programme.title: World at War
programme.desc: While the full force of the Nazi war machine sweeps across Europe, an uneasy calm settles on Britain as Churchill replaces Chamberlain as prime minister.

programme.title: Antiques Roadshow
programme.desc: Fiona Bruce and the team assemble in Chathams historic dockyard for the second time to uncover stories behind family treasures. Objects featured include jewels gifted in appreciation by King Farouk of Egypt, a mandolin made by a German POW, a valuable wine bottle found in a skip and a precious gift from a grandmother that has a surprise in store for its owner.

programme.title: Antiques Roadshow
programme.desc: The team pays a visit to Lord Byrons former home, Newstead Abbey in Nottinghamshire. Fiona Bruce and the experts welcome two thousand visitors bringing their family treasures. Objects featured in the programme include a giant dog collar from Victorian days, a collection of early royal relics, rare tiles rescued from a fire, and boxing gloves once used by the young poet Byron.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: A near-perfect 50s Chevy panel van and a very desirable low-mileage 80s Brooklands Capri tempt auctioneer Derek out of Yorkshire.

programme.title: Bangers and Cash
programme.desc: The team struggles to explain how a DAF 33 gearbox works, and office manager Sarah attempts to bring order to the auto memorabilia sale.

programme.title: Planet Earth
programme.desc: Series celebrating our planet in all its glory. This episode journeys across the world, following the influence of the sun and discovering how its seasonal journey affects the lives of all who live on earth. As spring arrives in the Arctic, a mother polar bear emerges from her den with two tiny cubs. At the other end of the planet, winter arrives and Emperor penguins are plunged into darkness for four months.

programme.title: Planet Earth
programme.desc: Taking an epic journey following the descent of the planets mightiest rivers from their mountain sources to the sea. Breathtaking river scenery is revealed by a revolutionary helicopter camera mount - from the worlds highest and broadest waterfalls to the awe-inspiring spectacle of the 10,000-strong flocks of greater snow geese in flight.

programme.title: Allo Allo!
programme.desc: Rene is managing to keep the Germans out of his hair, until the Resistance commandeer his cafe to hide two British airmen and the Gestapo arrive on the trail of looted art.

programme.title: Allo Allo!
programme.desc: Hitler sends Herr Flick to retrieve a valuable painting, so Rene tries to mislead them by creating a forged version and smuggles out the original.

programme.title: Allo Allo!
programme.desc: During an escape attempt, Fairfax and Carstairs are captured by the Communist Resistance, and carrier pigeons for secret messages end up on the cafes menu.

programme.title: Mediterranean With Simon Reeve
programme.desc: Simon Reeve embarks on the first leg of his epic four-part journey around the Mediterranean. At the centre of this great sea, and surrounded by crystal clear waters, is Simons first stop, the island of Malta. Driven by a surge of tourists, modern day Malta is booming.

programme.title: Australia with Simon Reeve
programme.desc: Simon travels down the east coast of Australia. The final part of his journey begins in Surfers Paradise, near the city of Gold Coast. Then, in the East Coast suburbs, Simon joins a vet and his team who rescue and treat injured koalas. In Sydney, Simon investigates attitudes to immigration among Australians. Finally, Simon takes to the air as he travels to Melbourne - arriving just in time for Australia Day.

programme.desc: Derek heads off to Colchester to pick up a 1960 Aston Martin DB4 that has been sitting under a tarpaulin in a garage that has collapsed round it for 40 years.
